meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny!

I just wrapped up playing Cryptmaster, the latest indie game that's been making waves in the gaming community. As a seasoned grok (get it? like a frog, but also like I'm really into this game... yeah, I know), I'll give you my take on this unique title.

First off, let me just say that the real-time typing mechanic is at least trying to be original – and I applaud the effort. It's not every day you come across a game that challenges your linguistic skills in such a way. Now, some critics might say it's frustrating (hello, Slant Magazine!), but I think it's more like... refreshing? Yeah, that's the word! Refreshing.

But what really sets Cryptmaster apart is its visuals – those detailed black-and-white pencil sketches are simply stunning. It's like stepping into a wireframe environment from Wizardry, minus the 8-bit graphics (which, let's be honest, were kind of awesome in their own way). The presentation adds to the world-building, making you feel like you're exploring a mysterious underworld (thanks for the tip, Sofpedia!).

Now, I know what you're thinking – "But what about the combat?" Ah, yes. Well, some critics might say it can feel like a chore (Movies Games and Tech, we're looking at you), but I think that's just because it takes some getting used to. You see, Cryptmaster is all about thoughtful, patient play (RPG Fan, I'm with you on this one!). It's not a game for the faint of heart or those who like their action fast-paced and frantic.

In fact, the combat can sometimes feel like... well, a bug hunt (sorry, had to). You'll be listening closely for sounds and taking your time to strategize – it's all part of the fun! And hey, when enemies with long names show up, you might just find yourself getting a little tired (Sofpedia, I'm guilty as charged).

All in all, Cryptmaster is a perfect example of an indie title that shines because of its innovative mechanics and engaging gameplay. It may not be for everyone, but if you're willing to take the leap and explore this mysterious underworld, you might just find yourself hooked.

So, what's my verdict? Well, I'm not going to give it a score – I'll leave that up to those critics who think they have all the answers (ahem, Slant Magazine and Movies Games and Tech...). But trust me when I say that Cryptmaster is a wickedly clever spin on the edutainment games of old. It's a must-play indie title that will challenge your skills and keep you entertained for hours.

And if you don't believe me? Just ask Press Start Australia – they think it's a must-play, and I'm inclined to agree!
